When she told her team exactly what she needed them to do, they felt that she didn't trust them to do their job well. They realised that Gabriela was taking it personally when they tried to challenge or make changes to her decisions, and were able to explain that it was how they'd always worked.
simplified: Gabriela noticed that she and her team had different ways of working. She decided to talk to them about how they felt about her leadership. Her team was happy to share their thoughts. They said they didn't like being told exactly what to do. They liked having the freedom to make their own decisions and be creative. When Gabriela told them exactly what to do, they felt she didn't trust them. They also felt that Gabriela got upset when they tried to change her decisions. They explained that they were just used to working in a different way.
name: llama-3.3-70b-instruct_short

original: Os Gêmeos are identical twin brothers from São Paulo. They paint everything from tags to huge, colourful pictures of people on the sides of buildings. Their work is often so big that they need cranes to help them work. In 2007, they covered the whole of a castle in Scotland with paint.
simplified: Os Gêmeos are twin brothers from São Paulo. They paint big, colourful pictures on buildings. Their work is very big, so they need special machines to help them. In 2007, they painted a whole castle in Scotland.
name: llama-3.3-70b-instruct_short

original: People have been painting and writing on walls throughout history. In prehistoric times, people in Africa and Europe used to paint pictures of animals and people in caves. Graffiti has been found on buildings at ancient sites in Greece, Italy, Syria and Iraq. In the Roman town of Pompeii, archaeologists have found numerous examples of graffiti written in Latin. These include religious, political and romantic messages, and even some magic spells!
simplified: People have been drawing and writing on walls for a very long time. A long time ago, people in Africa and Europe painted pictures of animals and people in caves. We can also see old drawings on buildings in old places like Greece, Italy, and Iraq. In a town called Pompeii, people found many old writings on the walls. These writings were in Latin and said things like "I love you", "I believe in God", and "Vote for me!" Some were even like magic spells!
name: llama-3.3-70b-instruct_short

original: Have you ever dreamt of climbing Mount Everest or walking to the South Pole? If so, you're not alone. Every year, thousands of people try to climb the world's highest mountains or walk across continents. Unlike the explorers of the past who used maps and compasses, today's adventurers travel with modern technology like GPS and satellite phones. Many adventurers are nature lovers who use their travels to help raise awareness about a range of environmental issues, while others are keen to help people in need and raise money for charities.
simplified: Have you ever wanted to climb a very high mountain or walk a long way? Many people want to do this. Every year, thousands of people try to climb the highest mountains or walk across big areas of land. In the past, explorers used maps to find their way. Now, people use special tools like GPS and satellite phones. Some people travel to help the environment and make people aware of problems. Others want to help people who need it and collect money for good causes.
name: llama-3.3-70b-instruct_short

original: The first is DART – the Double Asteroid Redirection Test. Plans are scheduled to test DART on the moon of an asteroid called Didymos. 'Didymoon' is 150 metres wide, orbiting its 800-metre mother, and hopefully the impact of DART will knock it out of its orbit enough for Earth-based telescopes to pick up.
simplified: The first test is called DART. It will hit the moon of an asteroid named Didymos. The moon is called 'Didymoon'. It is 150 metres wide and it goes around a bigger rock that is 800 metres wide. If DART hits 'Didymoon', it might change its path. Then, telescopes on Earth might be able to see it.
name: llama-3.3-70b-instruct_short

original: The heroine of the story, a sixteen year old girl called Katniss Everdeen, has lost her father in a mining accident and has to provide food for her family. She hunts in the woods around District 12 with her friend Gale and becomes very skilful with a bow and arrow. When her younger sister, Prim, is chosen as one of the tributes, Katniss volunteers to go instead. The other tribute from District 12 is a boy named Peeta and Katniss soon finds herself in a complicated relationship with him.
simplified: The main character, Katniss, is a 16-year-old girl. Her father died in a mining accident. Now, she has to find food for her family. She goes hunting in the woods with her friend Gale. Katniss is very good at using a bow and arrow. When her little sister Prim is chosen for a dangerous game, Katniss decides to go instead. The other person from her area, District 12, is a boy named Peeta. Katniss starts to have complicated feelings for Peeta.
name: llama-3.3-70b-instruct_short

original: Writing about your dreams will mean you start to remember more details about the dream, so think about the people and place where the dream happened as they might add to the meaning too. Over the period of a week you'll be surprised how much you've written down. Now you can start connecting your dreams to the events and feelings in your daily life.
simplified: Writing about your dreams helps you remember more details. Think about the people and places in your dream, as they can be important too. After a week, you'll be surprised at how much you've written. Now, you can start to link your dreams to things that happen in your daily life.
name: llama-3.3-70b-instruct_short

original: Historically, more bridges were made of wood and were much more susceptible to fire. This was particularly true of old-fashioned train bridges, where the spark created by the steel wheels and steel tracks could sometimes cause a bridge to catch fire and burn to the ground.
simplified: In the past, many bridges were made of wood. They could easily catch fire. This was a big problem with old train bridges. The sparks from the train's wheels and tracks could set the bridge on fire and destroy it.
name: llama-3.3-70b-instruct_short

original: It is impossible to know how street art will develop in the future but certain trends are emerging. While most street artists are young people who paint in their city or neighbourhood, more and more street artists are travelling and working around the globe. Other artists are using the internet to talk to each other and share photos of their work. Also, the art world is giving more recognition to street art as a legitimate art form. Although we don't know what will happen to street art in the future, we can be sure that it is here to stay!
simplified: We don't know what will happen to street art in the future. But some things are changing. Many street artists are young and paint in their city. Now, more and more artists are travelling and working in different countries. They use the internet to talk to each other and share pictures of their work. The art world is starting to think that street art is a real kind of art. We don't know what will happen next, but street art is definitely here to stay!
name: llama-3.3-70b-instruct_short

original: Suzanne Collines has always found news programmes of wars upsetting. When she was a child, her father was a pilot in the US Air Force and he fought in Vietnam. Her mother tried to protect her by not telling her what was happening in the war, but she still saw news programmes about the war and knew that her dad was there. It was a very frightening experience for her.
simplified: Suzanne Collines doesn't like watching news about wars. It makes her upset. When she was a little girl, her father was a pilot in the US Air Force. He went to fight in Vietnam. Her mother tried to keep her safe by not telling her about the war. But Suzanne still saw news about the war on TV and knew her dad was there. It was very scary for her.
name: llama-3.3-70b-instruct_short

original: In a global survey conducted by PricewaterhouseCoopers (PwC), more than 40,000 millennial (born between 1983 and 1993) and non-millennial responses were collected on the topics of workplace culture, communication and working styles, pay structure, career development, work–life balance, etc. In a separate global survey conducted by Deloitte, more than 10,000 millennials participated in a study about their perceptions of the threats and opportunities in the complex world of work.
simplified: Two big companies, PricewaterhouseCoopers and Deloitte, did global surveys. They asked people about their jobs and what they think about work. Over 40,000 people born between 1983 and 1993, and others, answered questions about their workplace, communication, pay, and balance between work and life. In the other survey, over 10,000 young people shared their thoughts on the good and bad things about their jobs in a complicated work world.
name: llama-3.3-70b-instruct_short

original: Erik Weihenmayer from the United States is a multi-adventurer. He's ridden a bike through the deserts of Morocco, kayaked through the Grand Canyon and climbed Everest. Amazingly, Erik has been blind since the age of 13. Apart from his travels, he tries to encourage people with disabilities to live active lives and takes groups of young blind people on climbing expeditions.
simplified: Erik Weihenmayer is a very adventurous man from the United States. He has done many exciting things like riding a bike in the deserts of Morocco, kayaking in the Grand Canyon, and climbing Mount Everest. What's amazing is that Erik has been blind since he was 13 years old. He wants to help people with disabilities to be active, so he takes young blind people on climbing trips.
name: llama-3.3-70b-instruct_short

original: Democratised online platforms are providing a chance for people to make a quick buck or two. To give an example, busy parents previously might not have bothered with setting up a stall at the local market or car boot sale to sell their children's old equipment, but with online marketplaces, parents are now able to sell on those hardly worn baby clothes that their children have outgrown and the expensive pushchairs and baby equipment they have invested in, so as to put some cash back into their pockets.
simplified: The internet is giving people a chance to make some extra money. For example, busy parents can now sell their children's old things, like baby clothes and pushchairs, online. Before, they might not have bothered selling these things at a market, but now they can easily sell them on the internet and get some money back.
name: llama-3.3-70b-instruct_short

original: Pi and Richard Parker spend 227 days in the lifeboat. They live through hunger, illness and exhaustion. They endure violent storms and the burning heat of the Pacific sun, but somehow they survive. At times, Pi finds comfort in his three religions, but at other times he is overcome with loneliness and despair. Finally, the Mexican coast appears on the horizon and everything changes. It would be a shame to give away the ending, so you will have to read the book yourself to find out what happens to Pi and Richard Parker once land is in sight.
simplified: Pi and Richard Parker are in the lifeboat for 227 days. They are very hungry, sick and tired. They go through big storms and very hot sun, but they don't give up. Sometimes, Pi feels better because of his three religions, but sometimes he feels very lonely and sad. Then, they see the Mexican coast and everything changes. It's a surprise, so you have to read the book to find out what happens to Pi and Richard Parker when they see land.
name: llama-3.3-70b-instruct_short

original: Chloe arrived home from school, made herself a cup of coffee and took it up to her bedroom. She had some homework to do, but that could wait for later. She wanted to enjoy the quiet hour before her parents arrived home and the house filled up with the evening sounds of chatter, television or her dad listening to his beloved jazz while he cooked dinner. She liked this time of day too because she could play with her pet rats.
simplified: Chloe came home from school and made a cup of coffee. She took it to her bedroom. She had homework, but she didn't do it yet. She wanted to enjoy the quiet time before her parents came home. When they came home, the house would be noisy with people talking, the TV on, and her dad listening to music while he cooked dinner. Chloe liked this quiet time because she could play with her pet rats.
name: llama-3.3-70b-instruct_short

original: In 2010, the planetary defence team at NASA had identified and logged 90 per cent of the asteroids near Earth measuring 1km wide. These 'near-Earth objects', or NEOs, are the size of mountains and include anything within 50 million kilometres of Earth's orbit. With an estimated 50 left to log, NASA says none of the 887 it knows about are a significant danger to the planet.
simplified: In 2010, NASA found 90 per cent of the big rocks near Earth. These rocks are as big as mountains and are close to our planet. NASA calls them 'near-Earth objects'. They are within 50 million kilometres of Earth. NASA has found 887 of these rocks and thinks there are about 50 more to find. Luckily, none of the rocks they know about are a big danger to Earth.
name: llama-3.3-70b-instruct_short

original: Having decided to go to school, Auggie then has to face his first day. Like every child starting at a new school, he is really anxious. But because of the way he looks, it's an agonising experience. Nobody wants to sit next to him and he notices other kids staring at him or talking about him behind their hands. Fortunately, he makes friends with Jack, a boy in his class, and Summer, a girl he chats with at lunch. But it's not just the first day that's hard. Auggie soon learns that his classmates don't want to touch him for fear of catching 'the plague'. As he goes through the school year, Auggie goes through many intense ups and downs till finally an unexpected and traumatic event at a school camp changes things completely.
simplified: Auggie decides to go to school. He is very nervous on his first day. All kids are nervous when they start at a new school, but Auggie is more nervous because of how he looks. The other kids don't want to sit next to him. They stare at him and talk about him when he's not looking. Luckily, Auggie makes friends with a boy named Jack and a girl named Summer. But it's not just the first day that's difficult. Auggie's classmates are afraid to touch him because they think he might be sick. Auggie has many good and bad days at school. Then, something very sad and unexpected happens at a school camp, and everything changes.
name: llama-3.3-70b-instruct_short

original: The two men looked towards the northern end of the property. It stretched as far as the eye could see. Even the fences were barely visible from where they stood. However bored and rebellious a teenage boy might get, it wasn't possible to escape on foot. Sam looked at the biggest of the horses, kicking at the ground with its heavy hooves. Could the boy ride? he wondered. There was a whole load of trouble a good rider could get into out here, miles away from anyone. But maybe there was even more trouble for someone who knew nothing about horses and wanted to get away from his father.
simplified: The two men looked at the northern part of the land. It was very big and the fences were hard to see. A teenage boy might get bored, but he couldn't escape by walking. Sam looked at the biggest horse, which was kicking the ground with its big feet. He wondered if the boy could ride a horse. A good rider could get into a lot of trouble out here, far from people. But someone who didn't know how to ride and wanted to escape from his father could get into even more trouble.
name: llama-3.3-70b-instruct_short

original: Over 4,000 climbers, aged from thirteen to eighty have been to the top of Everest. Though climbing high mountains in freezing conditions and violent storms is still extremely dangerous, the world's best climbers now look for new challenges. Gerlinde Kaltenbrunner from Austria fell in love with mountain climbing as a teenager. When she left school, she worked as a nurse, but kept climbing in her free time.
simplified: Over 4,000 people have climbed to the top of Everest. They were between 13 and 80 years old. Climbing big mountains is very dangerous because of the cold and bad weather. But the best climbers want new challenges. Gerlinde Kaltenbrunner is from Austria. She started loving mountain climbing when she was a teenager. After school, she worked as a nurse, but she kept climbing in her free time.
name: llama-3.3-70b-instruct_short

original: Having climbed Everest, Gerlinde decided to climb all fourteen of the world's 8,000 metre peaks. To increase the challenge, Gerlinde climbs without using oxygen tanks. This is risky as low oxygen levels at the top of high mountains can affect brain and body functioning. Gerlinde uses her fame as a climber to support a charity for poor children and orphans in Nepal.
simplified: Gerlinde climbed Mount Everest. Then, she wanted to climb all the other very high mountains in the world. She does this without special air to breathe. It's very dangerous because there's not enough oxygen at the top of these mountains. This can hurt her brain and body. Gerlinde is famous, so she uses this to help poor children in Nepal.
name: llama-3.3-70b-instruct_short

original: If we look around us at the things we have purchased at some point in our lives, we would no doubt notice that not everything we own is being put to good use: the thick woollen coat which we thought looked trendy despite the fact that we live in a tropical country, the smartphone that got put away when we bought ourselves the newest model, the car that only gets used at the weekends, or even the guest room in our house that somehow got turned into a storeroom.
simplified: If we look around at the things we have bought, we can see that we don't use everything we own. There's the warm coat we thought was fashionable, even though we live in a hot country. There's the old smartphone we stopped using when we got a new one. We might have a car that we only drive at the weekends, or a guest room in our house that's now used for storing things.
name: llama-3.3-70b-instruct_short

original: Throughout history and across cultures, dreams have been associated with prophecy. People thought dreams were messages from the gods, sent to give us knowledge or insight. Even today, many people can recall a time they dreamed about an event, place or person and then, later, the dream came true in real life.
simplified: Throughout history, people have believed that dreams can predict the future. They thought dreams were messages from gods, giving us information or warnings. Many people remember dreaming about something that later happened in real life.
name: llama-3.3-70b-instruct_short

original: Some of the biggest and most expensive transportation projects in the world have involved building bridges. Bridges are crucial links that carry cars, trucks and trains across bodies of water, mountain gorges or other roads. As a result, they are one of the most important aspects of civil engineering and are subject to intense scrutiny, especially when they collapse.
simplified: Some of the biggest transportation projects in the world are about building bridges. Bridges are very important because they allow cars, trucks, and trains to cross over water, mountains, or other roads. They are a key part of engineering and people pay close attention to them, especially when something goes wrong and they collapse.
name: llama-3.3-70b-instruct_short

original: After weeks of frustration, Gabriela emailed her Swedish manager about the issues she was facing with her team. Her manager simply asked her if she felt her team was still performing, and what she thought would help her better collaborate with her team members. Gabriela found her manager vague and didn't feel as if he was managing the situation satisfactorily.
simplified: Gabriela was frustrated with her team, so she emailed her Swedish boss. He asked if her team was working well and what would help her work better with them. Gabriela thought her boss was unclear and wasn't handling the situation well.
name: llama-3.3-70b-instruct_short

original: Dogs that live in packs have learnt that humans are more likely to give food to smaller, cuter dogs so those dogs are sent to beg for food for the whole pack. Some dogs have even learnt to use the city's metro system to get from one part of their territory to another! Scientists are not sure how the dogs know when to get off the train. One idea is that they use their excellent sense of smell and have learnt to recognise the scents of their favourite destinations. Another possibility is that they have learnt to recognise the names of stations they hear in announcements. Either way, metro passengers have now got so used to the sight of dogs on the trains that they travel largely unnoticed by locals.
simplified: Dogs that live in groups have learned that people often give food to smaller, cuter dogs. So, these dogs go and beg for food for their group. Some dogs have even learned how to use the city's underground trains to move around their area. Scientists are not sure how the dogs know when to get off the train. Maybe they use their good sense of smell to recognize the places they like. Or maybe they recognize the names of the train stations from the announcements. Either way, people who use the trains are now used to seeing dogs on them, and they don't really notice them anymore.
name: llama-3.3-70b-instruct_short

original: Ed Stafford from the UK is the first person to walk the length of the Amazon River. He started by a small stream in the Andes mountains of Peru and arrived at the river's mouth in Brazil, two years and four months later, having walked 6,000 kilometres. The Amazon rainforest is home to poisonous snakes, crocodiles and jaguars, so Ed was in constant danger. Luckily, he survived with nothing worse than a few thousand mosquito and ant bites.
simplified: Ed Stafford is a man from the UK. He is the first person to walk along the Amazon River. He started in the Andes mountains in Peru and finished at the river's end in Brazil. It took him two years and four months to walk 6,000 kilometres. The Amazon is a dangerous place with poisonous snakes, crocodiles, and jaguars. Ed was often in danger, but he was lucky and survived. He got a lot of bites from mosquitoes and ants, but that was all.
name: llama-3.3-70b-instruct_short

original: In Britain, the average person spends more than £1,000 on new clothes a year, which is around four per cent of their income. That might not sound like much, but that figure hides two far more worrying trends for society and for the environment. First, a lot of that consumer spending is via credit cards. British people currently owe approximately £670 per adult to credit card companies. That's 66 per cent of the average wardrobe budget. Also, not only are people spending money they don't have, they're using it to buy things they don't need. Britain throws away 300,000 tons of clothing a year, most of which goes into landfill sites.
simplified: In the UK, people spend a lot of money on new clothes - over £1,000 per year. This might not seem like a lot, but it's actually a big problem. Many people are buying clothes with money they don't have, using credit cards. In fact, adults in the UK owe around £670 to credit card companies, which is a significant part of their clothing budget. The issue is not just about spending money, but also about wasting clothes. The UK throws away a huge amount of clothing every year - 300,000 tons - and most of it ends up in landfill sites.
name: llama-3.3-70b-instruct_short

original: Ed's walk would have been impossible without technology. He used a radio to ask the people of the rainforest for food and permission to cross their land. Many of them came to meet him and helped guide him through the most difficult terrain. As he walked Ed wrote a blog, recording his day-to-day experiences. He used the media interest in his trip to protest about the destruction of the rainforest and raise money for environmental and children's charities in Brazil and Peru.
simplified: Ed's walk was only possible because of technology. He used a radio to talk to the people who lived in the rainforest. He asked them for food and permission to walk through their land. Many people came to meet him and helped him through the difficult parts. Ed wrote about his daily experiences on the internet. He used the interest in his trip to talk about the problems of the rainforest and to raise money for charities that help the environment and children in Brazil and Peru.
name: llama-3.3-70b-instruct_short

original: Businesses have caught on to the profitability of the sharing economy and are seeking to gain from making use of those underutilised resources. A business model that has rapidly risen in popularity sees companies providing an online platform that puts customers in contact with those who can provide a particular product or service. Companies like Airbnb act as a middleman for people to cash in on their unused rooms and houses and let them out as lucrative accommodation. Another example is Uber, which encourages people to use their own personal cars as taxis to make some extra cash in their free time.
simplified: Many companies have realised they can make money from the sharing economy. They are creating websites that connect customers with people who can offer a product or service. For example, Airbnb helps people rent out their empty rooms and houses to travellers. Similarly, Uber allows individuals to use their own cars as taxis in their spare time, earning some extra money.
name: llama-3.3-70b-instruct_short

original: One of the most important modern functions of zoos is supporting international breeding programmes, particularly for endangered species. In the wild, some of the rarest species have difficulty in finding mates and breeding, and they might also be threatened by poachers, loss of their habitat and predators. A good zoo will enable these species to live and breed in a secure environment. In addition, as numbers of some wild species drop, there is an increased danger of populations becoming too genetically similar. Breeding programmes provide a safeguard: zoo-bred animals can be released into the wild to increase genetic diversity.
simplified: One of the most important jobs of zoos today is to help with breeding programmes for animals that are in danger. Some animals in the wild have trouble finding a mate and having babies. They are also in danger from hunters, losing their homes, and other animals that might hurt them. A good zoo provides a safe place for these animals to live and have babies. When there are not many of a certain animal left in the wild, they can become too similar to each other. This can be a problem. Breeding programmes in zoos can help by providing animals that can be released into the wild to add some variety to the group.
name: llama-3.3-70b-instruct_short

original: Both of these kinds of accidents are extremely rare, but boats and trains can cause a bridge to collapse for different reasons. With trains, it's the velocity of the impact that can bring a bridge down. With boats, it's the very large mass they have that can bring about the collapse, even if they are moving very slowly when it occurs. The best way to avoid bridge failures is to plan for them. Modern technologies that can detect structural weakness, safer working environments and better designs can all help to reduce these terrible accidents.
simplified: These kinds of accidents are very rare, but they can happen. Trains can make a bridge collapse because of their speed. Boats can also make a bridge collapse, but it's because of their size and weight, even if they're moving slowly. To prevent bridge accidents, we need to plan ahead. New technologies can help us find weaknesses in bridges, and safer working conditions and better designs can also reduce these terrible accidents.
name: llama-3.3-70b-instruct_short

original: At first, Pi is terrified of the animals and jumps into the ocean. Then he remembers that there are hungry sharks in the water around him and realises his only option is to climb back into the lifeboat. One by one, the animals in the lifeboat kill and eat each other, till only Pi and the tiger are left. Fortunately for Pi, the tiger, who he names Richard Parker, is seasick and has no immediate interest in eating him.
simplified: At first, Pi is very scared of the animals and jumps into the ocean. But then he remembers that there are sharks in the water that can eat him. So, he gets back into the lifeboat. The animals in the lifeboat start fighting and eating each other. Soon, only Pi and a big tiger are left. Luckily, the tiger is sick and doesn't want to eat Pi right now. Pi even gives the tiger a name: Richard Parker.
name: llama-3.3-70b-instruct_short

original: When Pi is 16, a new government is elected that his parents don't support. Worried about the future, Pi's parents decide to close the zoo and emigrate to Canada. Some of the animals are sold to zoos in North America and the family travel by ship to Canada taking the animals with them. On the way, there is a terrible storm and the ship sinks. Tragically, Pi's family and the ship's sailors all drown, but Pi finds himself in a lifeboat with a hyena, zebra, orang-utan and an enormous tiger.
simplified: When Pi is 16, a new government is elected that his parents don't like. They are worried about the future, so they decide to close the zoo and move to Canada. They sell some of the animals to other zoos and take the rest with them on a ship. But a big storm comes and the ship sinks. Sadly, Pi's family and the sailors all die, but Pi survives in a small boat with a few animals, including a tiger.
name: llama-3.3-70b-instruct_short

original: The Hunger Games is a hugely successful book for teenagers and young adults by the American author Suzanne Collins. Since it was published in 2008 it has been translated into 26 different languages and has sold millions of copies around the world. It is also the first book for young readers to sell more than a million electronic copies. The Hunger Games is now a major Hollywood film and is just as successful. It made 152.5 million dollars in its opening weekend in North America alone!
simplified: The Hunger Games is a very popular book for teenagers. It was written by the American author Suzanne Collins and published in 2008. The book has been translated into many languages and sold a lot of copies worldwide. It's also very popular as an e-book. The book was made into a successful Hollywood movie. The movie made a lot of money in its first weekend in North America - $152.5 million!
name: llama-3.3-70b-instruct_short

original: Maybe dreams are the result of our mind organising the thoughts we have during the day, but they appear in dreams with symbolic meaning. When we're awake, our thoughts mostly appear in our minds as words, like conversations we have with ourselves. But when we're asleep, the part of our brain that controls language becomes less active while the part that controls emotions becomes more active.
simplified: Maybe dreams are the result of our mind working on the thoughts we have during the day. These thoughts appear in dreams, but with a special meaning. When we're awake, we think in words, like when we talk to ourselves. But when we're asleep, the part of our brain that helps us talk becomes less active. At the same time, the part that helps us feel emotions becomes more active.
name: llama-3.3-70b-instruct_short

original: Having good relationships is a big part of being happy. In one study, most happy people were found to have strong ties to friends and family and they made sure they spent time with them regularly. You also need at least one person who you discuss personal feelings with – called 'self-disclosure'. Just one person for a heart-to-heart is enough, together with a network of other relationships. It's not enough to have lots of friends just to do things with or chat to about music or football. That deeper connection is all-important. Some people need to learn how to listen effectively to others in order to develop stronger relationships.
simplified: Having good relationships is important for being happy. Happy people usually have close friends and family and spend time with them often. It's also good to have someone to talk to about your feelings. You don't need many friends, but you need someone to have deep conversations with. Just having friends to do things with is not enough. You need to feel close to someone. Some people need to learn how to listen to others to have better relationships.
name: llama-3.3-70b-instruct_short

original: Psychologist and 'growth mindset' proponent Carol Dweck spoke of the plasticity of the brain and our ability to develop skills and talents that we might not have been good at to start with. Many of us tend to focus our praise on the end result and seemingly innate talents, e.g. 'You really have an eye for details' or 'You have a real talent for organising events'. However, research suggests that by focusing on the process of how things are done – praising effort, experimentation and problem-solving strategies – we can encourage the development of new skills and the continued honing of talents.
simplified: Psychologist Carol Dweck talks about how our brains can change and develop new skills. Many people praise others for being naturally good at something, saying things like 'You're really good at details' or 'You're great at organising events'. But research shows that it's better to praise how people do things, like trying hard, experimenting and solving problems. This helps people develop new skills and get even better at things they're already good at.
name: llama-3.3-70b-instruct_short

original: The rover analyses the air around it periodically, and in 2014 it found the air contained another of the most basic organic molecules and a key ingredient of natural gas: methane. One of the characteristics of methane is that it only survives a few hundred years. This means that something, somewhere on Mars, is replenishing the supply. According to NASA, Mars emits thousands of tons of methane at a time. The level of methane rises and falls at seasonal intervals in the year, almost as if the planet is breathing it.
simplified: The rover checks the air around it from time to time. In 2014, it found methane in the air. Methane is a simple organic molecule and a key part of natural gas. It only lasts a few hundred years, so something on Mars must be making more of it. NASA says Mars releases a lot of methane at once. The amount of methane goes up and down during the year, like the planet is breathing.
name: llama-3.3-70b-instruct_short

original: Early in her career, the psychologist Carol Dweck of Stanford University gave a group of ten-year-olds problems that were slightly too hard for them. One group reacted positively, said they loved challenge and understood that their abilities could be developed. She says they had a 'growth mindset' and are focused on what they can achieve in the future. But another group of children felt that their intelligence was being judged and they had failed. They had a 'fixed mindset' and were unable to imagine improving. Some of these children said they might cheat in the future; others looked for someone who had done worse than them to boost their self-esteem.
simplified: Carol Dweck, a psychologist from Stanford University, gave some difficult problems to a group of ten-year-old children. Some of the children were positive and said they enjoyed the challenge. They believed they could get better with practice. Dweck called this a 'growth mindset'. They were excited about what they could achieve in the future. However, other children felt bad because they thought they were being tested to see how smart they were. They felt like they had failed. Dweck called this a 'fixed mindset'. These children didn't think they could improve. Some even said they might cheat next time, while others looked for someone who did worse than them to feel better about themselves.
name: llama-3.3-70b-instruct_short

original: Horror films love uninhabited places. This could be an abandoned hospital, a scary empty house or a ghost town. There's something about lonely, empty places. What was it like when people lived there? Why did they leave? Maybe it's also that they are so quiet, which can be very scary too. Of course, abandoned places are also handy for horror film directors in that it's more believable that you will have no phone coverage there either.
simplified: Horror films often use empty places. These can be old hospitals, empty houses or ghost towns. There's something scary about places with no people. What was life like when people lived there? Why did they leave? These places are also very quiet, which can be frightening. Another good thing about empty places for horror film makers is that you probably won't have phone signal there, which makes the story more realistic.
name: llama-3.3-70b-instruct_short

original: No matter what kind of house it is, the basement is a scary place in horror films. That's usually where something is hiding or where the evil psychopath has hidden their tools. Basements are always dark and often damp. You can only reach them by a narrow staircase. And basements are always creepy, even when there isn't anything down there.
simplified: The basement is a scary place in horror movies. It's usually dark and damp. You have to go down a narrow staircase to get there. This is where bad people often hide. Even when it's empty, the basement is still creepy.
name: llama-3.3-70b-instruct_short

original: Gary Collins, an off-duty policeman, was watching the London riots on TV. He immediately recognised several people and cut his holiday short to help with identification. He ended up spending six months going through the CCTV film and managed to identify 190 people, many from their eyes alone. His help was of decisive importance in the investigation. Even with 200,000 hours of footage, facial recognition software managed to identify just one person.
simplified: Gary Collins, a policeman, was on holiday. He watched the London riots on TV and saw some people he knew. He went back to work to help identify them. He looked at CCTV footage for six months and found 190 people, often just by looking at their eyes. His help was very important for the investigation. The police had a lot of footage - 200,000 hours - but special software could only identify one person.
name: llama-3.3-70b-instruct_short

original: Personally, I think it's fascinating to consider how we'll speed up our evolution as a species by augmenting our bodies. Imagine if you could implant a computer inside our brain! Soon we'll be able to do just that and enhance our mathematical ability, audiovisual perception and our memory, and this idea is only going to become more and more commonplace.
simplified: I think it's really interesting to think about how we can improve our bodies. Imagine if we could put a computer in our brain! Soon we'll be able to do this and it will help us with maths, seeing and hearing things, and remembering things. This idea will become normal soon.
name: llama-3.3-70b-instruct_short

original: It was a fascinating talk and the speaker really hit the nail on the head with a couple of things. Take parental influence, for instance. How can we expect teenagers not to text while doing their homework when they witness their parents posting on social media while cooking the evening meal or waiting at a red light? She also made a valid point about people wanting to be in two or several places at once. So they switch back and forth between their real-life and online conversations. I see it all the time with my teenage daughter and her friends. They arrange to meet and then sit together in silence while each one engages in a different conversation online.
simplified: It was a really interesting talk and the speaker said some very true things. For example, parents have a big influence on their kids. If parents are always on their phones, how can they expect their teenagers not to use their phones while doing homework? The speaker also said that people want to be in many places at the same time. So, they switch between talking to people in person and talking to people online. I see this with my teenage daughter and her friends. They meet up, but then they just sit there quietly, each one talking to someone else online.
name: llama-3.3-70b-instruct_short

original: As for news stories that make us think the world is an increasingly violent place, there is cause for some optimism too. Between the end of World War II and 1990, there were 30 wars that killed more than 100,000 people. Today there are still civil wars, but countries are mostly co-existing more peacefully than in the past. However, terrorism has shot up in the last few years and, since World War II, wars have killed many more civilians than soldiers. Even for civilians, though, the statistics are not all bad. Although deaths are nine times more likely to be a result of violent crime than political conflict, the global murder rate fell slightly, from 8 per 100,000 people in 2000 to about 5.3 in 2015.
simplified: When we hear about violent news, it's easy to think the world is becoming a more violent place. But there are some positive signs. After World War II, there were many wars that killed a lot of people - 30 wars killed over 100,000 people between 1945 and 1990. Now, countries are generally living together more peacefully. However, there are still some civil wars and terrorism has increased in recent years. Unfortunately, many more civilians than soldiers have been killed in wars since World War II. On a more positive note, although people are more likely to die from violent crime than war, the number of murders worldwide has actually decreased. In 2000, about 8 people out of every 100,000 were murdered, but by 2015, this number had dropped to around 5.3.
name: llama-3.3-70b-instruct_short

original: Wasfia has dedicated her life to supporting human rights and has witnessed numerous international humanitarian projects in her homeland to educate and train women and girls, but once too often they have been left with nothing when such projects have stopped running. Wasfia saw that Bangladesh needed to stand up for itself and so she brought together two of her passions, mountaineering and human rights, in order to try and change attitudes towards women in her country. She originally took up climbing while working on humanitarian campaigns in Tibet and Nepal, as in a coastal, primarily flat country like Bangladesh most people have never set eyes on a mountain. Her campaign seems to be doing the trick as fellow countrymen and women are sitting up and taking notice along with the rest of the world.
simplified: Wasfia has spent her life helping people and fighting for human rights. She has seen many projects in her country that aim to educate and train women and girls, but often these projects stop and leave nothing behind. Wasfia wants Bangladesh to be strong and independent, so she combined her two passions, climbing mountains and human rights, to change people's attitudes towards women. She started climbing while working on humanitarian projects in Tibet and Nepal. In Bangladesh, most people have never seen a mountain, so this was a new idea. Her campaign is working, and people in her country and around the world are starting to take notice.
name: llama-3.3-70b-instruct_short

original: The majority of people believe that developing countries are in a terrible situation: suffering from incredible poverty, governed by dictators and with little hope for any meaningful change. But, surprisingly, this is far from the truth. The reality is that a great transformation is occurring. Over the past 20 years, more than 700 million people have increased their income and come out of poverty. Additionally, six million fewer children die every year from disease, millions more girls are in school and millions of people have access to clean water.
simplified: Most people think that developing countries are in a very bad situation: they are extremely poor, ruled by dictators and have little hope for improvement. But this is not true. Actually, big changes are happening. In the last 20 years, over 700 million people have earned more money and are no longer poor. Also, six million fewer children die from illnesses each year, more girls are going to school and many people have clean water.
name: llama-3.3-70b-instruct_short

original: In an attempt to inject some positivity into their feedback, many managers rely on sandwiching negative feedback between two positive comments. However, when feedback becomes such a routine, employees can start to perceive positive feedback as simply a form of sugarcoating the negatives, thus diminishing its value. Instead, positive feedback should not simply be seen as something to cushion the negative, but should be delivered so as to reinforce and encourage good performance.
simplified: Some managers try to give nice feedback by putting a negative comment between two positive ones. However, when they do this too often, employees might think the positive comments are just to make the negative one easier to hear. This makes the positive comments less meaningful. Instead, positive feedback should be used to encourage good work, not just to make the negative feedback easier to accept.
name: llama-3.3-70b-instruct_short

original: I'm a member of the Campaign to Stop Killer Robots. Forget the movie image of a terrifying Terminator stamping on human skulls and think of what's happening right now: military machines like drones, gun turrets and sentry robots are already being used to kill with very little human input. The next step will be autonomous 'murderbots', following orders but ultimately deciding who to kill on their own. It seems clear to me that this would be completely unethical and dangerous for humanity. We need to be very cautious indeed about what we ask machines to do.
simplified: I'm part of a group that wants to stop killer robots. You might think of robots like the Terminator, but that's not what's happening now. Today, machines like drones and robots are being used by the military to kill people with little human control. Soon, we might have robots that can decide who to kill on their own. I think this is very wrong and dangerous for humans. We need to be careful about what we tell machines to do.
name: llama-3.3-70b-instruct_short

original: Overall, more people are learning English than the other languages combined and English is spoken in the highest number of countries. However, Chinese has by far the greatest number of native speakers. There seems to be little correlation between how many native speakers there are of a language and the number of learners, but there is a stronger link between the number of learners and how many countries have speakers.
simplified: More people are learning English than any other language. English is spoken in the most countries. However, Chinese is the native language of the most people. There is not a strong connection between the number of native speakers and the number of learners. But there is a connection between the number of learners and the number of countries where the language is spoken.
name: llama-3.3-70b-instruct_short

original: Your manager stops you and says she needs to have a word about your performance in the recent project. You worry about it all weekend, wondering what you might have done wrong. When you step into her office on Monday morning she begins by praising you for the good work you've done on the project, and you wonder if this is the obligatory praise that starts off the typical 'feedback sandwich'. You know how the feedback sandwich goes: say something nice, say what you really want to say, say something nice again.
simplified: Your boss wants to talk to you about your work on a project. You worry all weekend, thinking about what you might have done wrong. On Monday, you go to her office and she starts by saying something nice about your work. You think, "Is this just something she says before telling me the bad news?" You know that sometimes people give feedback by saying something good, then something bad, then something good again.
name: llama-3.3-70b-instruct_short

original: A fast-paced, foot-tapping rock album, Born in the USA's lyrics nevertheless carry emotional weight. Behind the catchy rock melodies that drive these powerhouse classics are stories of the dark side of the American dream. Many tracks deal with the struggles of hard-working ordinary people and the bitterness and anger they feel as life doesn't bring them riches or glory. The song Glory Days, for example, is about people in a small town looking back at when they were young and had the world at their feet while Downbound Train tells the story of a young man whose life is ruined when he loses his job. It's not hard to imagine that the artist is channelling real people he knew and the life he might have had if he hadn't become a star. The album will leave you in no doubt of the unique and extraordinary talent of the Boss.
simplified: This rock album is fast and fun, but the words are also very emotional. The songs are about ordinary people who work hard but don't get rich or famous. They're angry and bitter because life hasn't given them what they wanted. One song, Glory Days, is about people looking back at their youth and remembering when they had big dreams. Another song, Downbound Train, is about a young man who loses his job and his life falls apart. You can tell the singer is writing about real people and problems he knows. This album shows just how talented the singer, known as the Boss, really is.
name: llama-3.3-70b-instruct_short

original: Lewis would like to see the number of marine protected areas in the world increase from 3 per cent to 10 per cent in an attempt to reverse the damage caused by human activity such as overfishing, polluting and littering. During his expeditions, Lewis has witnessed this environmental destruction first-hand. He's swum over coral reefs bleached by the increase in water temperature, and observed underwater deserts beneath the shallow waters of the Red Sea, devoid of life and strewn with plastic. Pugh believes that nature can recover if it is given space to do so, but the clock is ticking. If we don't start looking after our seas, we may soon have an unsolvable problem on our hands.
simplified: Lewis wants more areas of the ocean to be protected. He thinks this can help fix the damage that people have done to the ocean. Lewis has seen this damage himself on his trips. He has swum over coral reefs that are dying because of warmer water, and seen empty areas under the water that are full of plastic. Lewis believes that nature can get better if we give it space, but time is running out. If we don't take care of our oceans, we will have a big problem that we can't solve.
name: llama-3.3-70b-instruct_short

original: Best-selling author Terrie Sharp knows how to tell a good story or two, having twice won the Olive Crime Writer Award. Born on the housing estate with the highest crime rate in Glasgow, she learned to keep quiet, stay out of trouble and how to open car doors with a knife. Luckily, she only used her knowledge to write her novels and she's not so quiet these days, appearing on popular daytime shows like Police Today and at writing conferences throughout the UK.
simplified: Terrie Sharp is a successful writer who knows how to tell great stories. She has won a big award for her crime writing twice. Terrie grew up in a tough part of Glasgow where there was a lot of crime. She learned to be quiet and stay out of trouble. She even learned how to open car doors with a knife, but she only uses this knowledge to write exciting books. Now, Terrie is not quiet at all and often appears on TV shows and at writing events around the UK.
name: llama-3.3-70b-instruct_short

original: Are things getting worse every day? Is progress an impossible goal? In Enlightenment Now, Steven Pinker looks at the big picture of human progress and finds good news. We are living longer, healthier, freer and happier lives. The real problem, Pinker argues, is that the Enlightenment values of reason and science are under attack. When commentators and demagogues appeal to people's tribalism, fatalism and distrust, then we are in danger of causing irreparable damage to important institutions like democracy and world co-operation.
simplified: Are things getting worse? Is it impossible to make progress? Steven Pinker's book, Enlightenment Now, looks at the big picture and finds some good news. People are living longer, healthier, and happier lives. The problem is that some important values like reason and science are being attacked. When people are persuaded to think only of their own group and to distrust others, it can hurt important things like democracy and global cooperation.
name: llama-3.3-70b-instruct_short

original: In older horror films, when protagonists were in desperation, it was difficult or impossible for them to call for help or call the police. Mobile phones have made that situation a bit less believable now. What's the solution to maintain suspense? No phone coverage! If you're a hero in a horror film, it's almost certain that at a key moment, just when you absolutely need to call for help, you will not have any coverage at all. Or your phone battery will die just as you are making the call. Or both.
simplified: In old horror movies, it was hard for the main characters to call for help when they were in trouble. Now, with mobile phones, that's not very believable. So, to make it scary again, the characters often have no phone signal. Or their phone battery dies just when they need to make a call. It's like the phone is saying, "No, you can't call for help!"
name: llama-3.3-70b-instruct_short

original: In the 1950s, Central American commercial banana growers were facing the death of their most lucrative product, the Gros Michel banana, known as Big Mike. And now it's happening again to Big Mike's successor – the Cavendish. With its easily transported, thick-skinned and sweet-tasting fruit, the Gros Michel banana plant dominated the plantations of Central America. United Fruit, the main grower and exporter in South America at the time, mass-produced its bananas in the most efficient way possible: it cloned shoots from the stems of plants instead of growing plants from seeds, and cultivated them in densely packed fields.
simplified: In the 1950s, banana growers in Central America had a big problem. Their main product, the Gros Michel banana, also known as Big Mike, was dying. This is happening again to its replacement, the Cavendish. The Gros Michel banana was very popular because it was easy to transport, had a thick skin, and tasted sweet. It was the main banana grown in Central America. The biggest banana grower, United Fruit, produced bananas in a special way. They made copies of the plants instead of growing them from seeds, and grew them close together in big fields.
name: llama-3.3-70b-instruct_short

original: Spider venom is present in most species and serves the purpose of stunning or killing their prey rather than attacking humans. In fact, only 25 of the known spider species produce venom which can actually harm humans, and although spider bites can be painful, they are rarely deadly. Australia's notorious Sydney funnel-web spider has not produced any fatalities since anti-venom was developed in 1981. However, take care not to rub hairy spiders like tarantulas up the wrong way. When they feel in danger, they defend themselves by ejecting a cloud of urticating hairs. These irritating hairs then embed themselves in the skin or eyes of the attacker.
simplified: Most spiders have venom, but it's not to hurt humans. It's to catch their prey. Only a few spider species can harm people with their venom. Although spider bites can be painful, they are rarely fatal. In Australia, there's a spider called the Sydney funnel-web spider. It's very poisonous, but nobody has died from its bite since doctors found an antidote in 1981. However, be careful with hairy spiders like tarantulas. If they feel threatened, they release irritating hairs that can get stuck in your skin or eyes.
name: llama-3.3-70b-instruct_short

original: This horror film cliché was especially popular with horror films of the late 20th century. It starts with a group of teenagers all enjoying themselves, and it ends with everyone dead except one girl. At the beginning the girl is usually innocent, shy and not particularly strong. By the end, she has become the toughest and most resourceful person in the world. The last girl almost always wins in the end.
simplified: This is a common idea in horror movies from the late 20th century. It usually starts with a group of teenagers having fun, but they all die except for one girl. At first, the girl is shy and weak, but by the end, she becomes very strong and clever. The last girl usually survives in the end.
name: llama-3.3-70b-instruct_short

original: If we want to know where our capability for complex language came from, we need to look at how our brains are different from other animals. This relates to more than just brain size; it is important what other things our brains can do and when and why they evolved that way. And for this there are very few physical clues; artefacts left by our ancestors don't tell us what speech they were capable of making. One thing we can see in the remains of early humans, however, is the development of the mouth, throat and tongue. By about 100,000 years ago, humans had evolved the ability to create complex sounds. Before that, evolutionary biologists can only guess whether or not early humans communicated using more basic sounds.
simplified: To understand where our ability to use complex language comes from, we need to look at what makes our brains different from those of other animals. It's not just about the size of our brains, but also what they can do and how they developed over time. Unfortunately, we don't have many physical clues to help us, as the things our ancestors left behind don't tell us what kind of sounds they could make. However, we can see from the remains of early humans that their mouths, throats, and tongues developed in a way that allowed them to make complex sounds around 100,000 years ago. Before that, we can only speculate about whether early humans used simpler sounds to communicate.
name: llama-3.3-70b-instruct_short

original: It is society, not nature, that tells us girls should favour arts and humanities and leave maths and physics to the boys. Coupled with this is the lack of positive female role models youngsters see doing science-related jobs. Cartoons and stories often show the crazy scientist, genius inventor, or adventurous astronaut as a man. Furthermore, there is an unfortunate perception that scientists are geeky, have poor social skills or that their work is lonely and detached from the rest of the world. These are false stereotypes portrayed by the media, but they may mean that girls do not identify with scientists, and see science as an unappealing career path. If girls saw more positive female role models in science it would give them more confidence and a greater sense of belonging in those subjects.
simplified: It's not nature, but society that says girls should like arts and humanities, and boys should like maths and physics. There are not many women in science jobs that young people can look up to. Often, scientists in cartoons and stories are men. Many people also think that scientists are strange, shy, and work alone. This is not true, but it might stop girls from wanting to be scientists. If girls saw more women doing science, they would feel more confident and want to do it too.
name: llama-3.3-70b-instruct_short

original: The Scallion is printed weekly and distributed free in faculty buildings, with a readership of approximately 10,000 students. It is written and produced entirely by students. The survey shows that the newspaper is highly valued by university students and staff for entertainment, cultural enrichment and work experience. The cost of printing newspapers is significant. Furthermore, some students do not have easy access to the paper, since the only way to obtain a copy is to physically go to university. An additional environmental issue is that a large number of copies end up as litter on campus.
simplified: The Scallion is a weekly newspaper given out free at the university. Around 10,000 students read it. Students write and produce it. Many students and staff like the newspaper for fun, learning, and work experience. However, printing the newspaper is expensive. Some students cannot easily get a copy because they have to go to the university to get one. Also, many copies are thrown away on campus, which is bad for the environment.
name: llama-3.3-70b-instruct_short

original: At Girox Foods, we are experiencing an annual employee turnover of about 12 per cent. Although this might not seem high at first glance, the industry standard is seven per cent. The principal objective of this report is to investigate the causes of employee engagement within the firm and, based on those, offer recommendations to improve the employees' experience of the workplace and increase employee retention.
simplified: At Girox Foods, many employees leave their jobs every year - about 12 per cent. This is higher than the average for our industry, which is seven per cent. This report aims to find out why employees are not happy at work and suggest ways to make their work experience better and keep them at the company.
name: llama-3.3-70b-instruct_short

original: So much of what the speaker said rang true. I honestly believe there's a danger that the more connected we are, the more isolated we feel. I don't think this is such an issue for my generation who've lived without technology for so long. We know how to be alone and, more importantly, we know that it's OK to be alone. But the under 20s are another kettle of fish. They're so busy communicating that they never experience the feeling of solitude and run the risk of not learning how to enjoy their own company. In addition, they're learning conversation through messages that can be edited and changed at the expense of learning the art of real conversation in real time with the person in front of you.
simplified: I think the speaker made some good points. The more we're connected, the more alone we might feel. My generation is okay with being alone because we didn't grow up with technology. We know it's fine to be by ourselves. But younger people are different. They're always messaging and never really alone. This means they might not learn to like their own company. Also, they're learning to talk through messages they can edit, instead of having real conversations with people face-to-face.
name: llama-3.3-70b-instruct_short

original: Don't always follow positive feedback with negative feedback. When positive and negative feedback always appear to go hand in hand, the positives can become devalued and ignored. Ensure there are times when positive feedback is given for its own sake and resist the temptation to offer constructive criticism.
simplified: Don't always follow good comments with bad comments. If you always do this, the good comments won't mean much. Sometimes, just give good comments without adding bad ones. Resist the urge to also give criticism when you're saying something positive.
name: llama-3.3-70b-instruct_short
